Loneliness is often deadly, and U.S. Surgeon General Dr. @vivek_murthy '80 has long spoken out about this often overlooked public health crisis. We'll be live-tweeting as Yale SOM welcomes back Dr. Murthy for a Leaders Forum talk on "Tackling Loneliness in Business & Society."

Dr. Murthy knows loneliness well, and the fear of seeming unlovable. The good news, he says, is we can all help. You don't need a medical degree or be a psychologist to address loneliness—being willing to reach out is enough, see how they are and invite them into a conversation.
Coda: Dr. Murthy graduated in '03. Apologies for this live-tweeter's typo. As the good doctor said: "People want to be known as human beings and not just a skill set."
The US Surgeon General normally has an MD. The current one, Vivek Murthy, also has an MBA, and he's put it to good use.

Dr. Murthy is speaking with Dean @KerwinKCharles, who asks why he returned as surgeon general. "It was a big decision, but it wasn't a hard decision," Dr. Murthy says. "When people around you are struggling...it's all of our jobs to step up and do whatever we can in that moment."

As he wraps up, Dr. Murthy urges the students in the audience to fulfill SOM's mission to be leaders for business & society. "Businesses that are fueled by kindness and compassion are good places to work. We all have the power to be healers because we all have the power to love."

It can be especially difficult for men to show the vulnerability essential to human growth, says Dr. Murthy. Many men grow up thinking that "masculinity is about not needing other people, and not showing emotion." The very opposite is true, he says, and it can be life or death.

In his role as surgeon general, Dr. Murthy says, he sees anger and division, disharmony and depression, anxiety and loneliness, adults experiencing isolation and children experiencing social media addiction. "People across America know that something isn't quite right."
Grassroots organizations are where people are, says Dr. Murthy. Trusting and listening to people with authority in a given community is key.

When he was young, @Surgeon_General watched his parents—themselves healthcare providers—struggle with lack of reimbursement for spending "too much" time with patients. "We pay people in healthcare for what they do to people, not the time they spend with people." That must change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed some of the deep inequalities in the healthcare system, not just for patients but for providers. Dr. Murthy stresses that we must make mental health access and care accessible to lower-paid health workers, who have always been "essential."

.@Surgeon_General sings the praises of the momoi, a five-person social network that originated in Japan. He formed a momoi with friends to talk honestly about health, finances, relationships, and fears. "That simple commitment changed my life. It has made me a better leader."

"In Okinawa, Japan, a place where the average life expectancy for women is around 90…people form a kind of social network called a moai — a group of five friends who offer social, logistic, emotional and even financial support for a lifetime." https://t.co/jX1zNJFqY9

As the saying goes, it's lonely at the top. For leaders, Dean @KerwinKCharles says, "The space for vulnerability shrinks as they move up." What advice would Dr. Murthy give him? Just asking the question shows strength: "Strong leaders are people who are willing to be vulnerable."

It makes us feel even lonelier to retreat, says @Surgeon_General. One remedy is acts of service. Dr. Murthy is leading initiatives to "help us rebuild connection and community in America, not just for our health but the health of our society and the functioning of our democracy."

Wherever Dr. Murthy goes—in the U.S. and around the world—people literally whisper to him that they struggle with loneliness. But humankind could not have survived in a state of loneliness, he says. "It's contrary to evolution. We have evolved to be better together."

Making work less lonely requires just a bit of effort and structure, says @Surgeon_General. At his staff meetings, colleagues share photos and stories that are interesting and personal. This way, they learn something about what has shaped their workmates and who they are.

When it comes to work, says @Surgeon_General, loneliness has a major impact on productivity, creativity, and retention. He cites the work of his former Yale SOM professor, the late Sigal Barsade, whose research influenced him a great deal. https://t.co/nQSWQcjLq5

Social isolation is one of @Surgeon_General's keenest focuses of interest. 60% of people struggle with loneliness—more than struggle with diabetes. Among young people, the numbers are even higher. This increases depression, anxiety, dementia, and many more serious health issues.
